{{Multiple image |total_width=310 |image1=Htou reverse - cropped.jpg |image2=Htou obverses.jpg |footer=The feather-like back design (left) and the eight General cards, each marked with the symbol of its suit, from a full eight-suited deck (right).}}
'''Tujeon''' are the traditional [[playing cards]] of [[Korea]].<ref name=world>{{cite web |url=http://www.wopc.co.uk/korea/ |title=Playing Cards in Korea |author=Simon Wintle |work=The World of Playing Cards |accessdate=November 13, 2012}}</ref>. Korean writing of Tujeon is {{ko-hhrm|hangul=투전|hanja=鬪牋|rr=tujeon|mr=t'ujŏn}}, with the literal meaning of ''fighting tablets''. A deck typically contains forty, sixty or eighty cards: nine numeral cards, and one General (''jang''), to each suit.<ref name=world /><ref name=harvard>{{cite web |url=http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~hou01454 |title=Playing Cards: Guide |author=James Edward Whitney, jr. |year=2003 |work=Harvard University Library Online Archival Search Information System |publisher=Harvard College |accessdate=November 14, 2012}}</ref> In a full eight-suited deck, the suits and their generals are as follows:<ref name=culin>{{cite book |title=Korean Games, with notes on the corresponding games of China and Japan |first=Stewart |last=Culin |publisher=University of Pennsylvania |location=Philadelphia |year=1895 |pages=123–126 |url=http://openlibrary.org/works/OL4288127W/Korean_games_with_notes_on_the_corresponding_games_of_China_and_Japan |accessdate=November 13, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Yi>{{cite book|last1=Yi|first1=I-Hwa|title=Korea's Pastimes and Customs: A Social History|date=2006|publisher=Hangilsa Publishing Co.|location=Hong Kong|page=29|edition=1st American}}</ref> *Man ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=사람|rr=saram|mr=saram}}) led by the King *Fish ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=물고기|rr=mulgogi|mr=mulgogi}}) led by the Dragon *Crow ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=까마귀|rr=ggamagwi|mr=kkamagwi}}) led by the Phoenix *Pheasant ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=꿩|rr=ggyeong|mr=kkwŏng}}) led by the Falcon *Roe deer ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=노루|rr=noru|mr=noru}}) led by the Tiger *Star ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=별|rr=byeol|mr=pyŏl}}) led by the North Star *Rabbit ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=토끼|rr=toggi|mr=t'okki}}) led by the Eagle *Horse ({{ko-hhrm|hangul=말|rr=mal|mr=mal}}) led by the Wagon The physical cards are very long and narrow, typically measuring about {{convert|8|in|mm}} tall and {{convert|0.5|in|mm}} across.<ref name=bones /> They are made of oiled paper, leather or silk.<ref name=world /><ref name=bones /> The backs are usually decorated with a stylized feather design.<ref name=chess />
==History== In his 1895 book ''Korean Games, with notes on the corresponding games of China and Japan'', ethnographer [[Stewart Culin]] suggested that tujeon originated from the similarly-shaped symbolic bamboo "arrows" [[belomancy|used for divination]] in sixth-century Korea.<ref name=world /><ref name=bones>{{cite book |title=Roll the Bones: the History of Gambling |first=David G. |last=Schwartz |publisher=Gotham Books |location=New York |year=2006 |isbn=1-59240-208-9 |pages=41–42}}</ref> This hypothesis, however, is supported mainly by visual similarity,<ref name=bones /> and remains unsubstantiated.<ref name=world />
Writing from the early 19th century, [[:ko:이규경|Yi Gyugyeong]] (1788-1856) claimed that [[:ko:장현 (조선)|Jang Hyeon]] (b. 1613) brought the Chinese card game of [[Madiao]] back to Korea.<ref name=Yi /> Yi also claimed Jang simplified the cards to create tujeon while in prison and taught the game to prisoners and guards. Jang himself is believed to have died in prison. King [[Jeongjo of Joseon|Jeongjo]] (r. 1776-1800) issued several ineffective bans against tujeon after gambling was causing serious social problems.
By the early 19th century, tujeon evolved somewhat from its original form: decks were typically only forty to sixty cards in size, using four or six of the eight suits; and the numeral cards were no longer marked to distinguish their suit, being used interchangeably. Only the generals kept their suits.<ref name=chess>{{cite book |title=Chess and Playing Cards |first=Stewart |last=Culin |publisher=University of Pennsylvania |location=Atlanta, Georgia |year=1896 |pages=918–919 |url=http://openlibrary.org/books/OL14127838M/Chess_and_playing_cards. |accessdate=November 13, 2012}}</ref> The cards were replaced by [[hanafuda]] during the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese occupation]] but some tujeon rules were transferred over to the Japanese cards.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Sylvia|title=All Cards on the Table|date=1990|publisher=Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum|location=Leinfelden|page=200}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fairbairn|first1=John|title=Modern Korean Cards - A Japanese Perspective|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=1991|volume=20|issue=2|pages=76-80}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20050219223033/http://hana.kirisame.org/sutda.html Sutda] (archived) at hana.kirisame.org. Retrieved 13 November 2016.</ref>
==Games== By far the most popular game was ''gabo japgi'', so much so that the name was used interchangeably with tujeon.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Sylvia|title=All Cards on the Table|date=1990|publisher=Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum|location=Leinfelden|page=335|ref=Mann}}</ref> Also known as ''yeot bang mangyi'' (엿방망이, "sweetmeat pestle"), it is a [[baccarat (card game)|baccarat]]-like game related to the [[Chinese domino]] game ''kol-ye-si'' (골여시).<ref name=culin /><ref>[http://www.domino-play.com/Games/KolYeSi.htm Kol-Ye-Si rules] at domino-play. Retrieved 5 November 2015.</ref> It is played with the 60 card deck and the object is to reach ''gabo'' or ''kapo'' which is gambling slang for 9. The game seems to be derived from [[Kabufuda]] games where the goal is to reach ''kabu'' or ''kaho'' which is also slang for 9. Both ''kabu'' and ''kapo'' are possibly descended from the Portuguese ''cavo'' which was slang for a stake or wager.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fairbairn|first1=John|title=A Card Game Played with Kurofuda|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=1986|volume=15|issue=1|page=27|ref=Fairbairn}}</ref> Another similar game is Komi, played with [[Ganjifa]] cards, from [[Odisha]], India along Portugal's old trade routes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hopewell|first1=Jeff|title=Komi and Nakash|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=2006|volume=34|issue=1|page=67|ref=Hopewell}}</ref> Baccarat did not appear in Europe until mid-19th century France and was preceded by a simpler game called [[Baccarat (card game)#Macao|Macao]], further hinting at a Portuguese connection.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parlett|first1=David|title=Related face count games|url=http://www.davpar.eu/histocs/blackjack.html#rels|website=Historic Card Games|accessdate=1 August 2015|ref=Parlett}}</ref> Another possible point of origin is China, where the games of [[Pai Gow]] ([[Chinese dominoes|dominoes]]) and ''San zhang'' ([[Chinese playing cards|cards]]) also have the target of reaching 9 but they are also more complicated and award bonuses for certain combinations.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lo|first1=Andrew|title=Pan Zhiheng's 'Xu Yezi Pu' (Sequel to a Manual of Leaves) - Part 2|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=2003|volume=31|issue=6|pages=278–281}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=McLeod|first1=John|title=Playing the Game: Partition games|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=2004|volume=32|issue=4|pages=173–175}}</ref>
Another popular game was ''dong dang'' (동당), an early [[rummy]] game similar to [[Khanhoo]].<ref name=culin />
==In popular culture== Playing the Tujeon cards is a theme used in several period drama series. Among them: * The fight between Kim Gong-ryang and Prince Gwanghae in Ep. 08 of [[The King's Face]]. (to be completed)

{{multiple issues| {{essay|date=May 2012}} {{original research|date=May 2012}} }}
'''Wet [[nanotechnology]]''' (also known as '''wet nanotech''') involves working up to large masses from small ones.<ref name="contemptech"/>
Wet nanotechnology requires [[water]] in which the process occurs.<ref name="contemptech"/> The process also involves chemists and biologists trying to reach larger scales by putting together individual molecules.<ref name="contemptech">[http://faculty.tamu-commerce.edu/dyeager/599/newtechnologyparti_files/v3_slide0205.htm] Contemporary Tech {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720055834/http://faculty.tamu-commerce.edu/dyeager/599/newtechnologyparti_files/v3_slide0205.htm |date=July 20, 2011 }}</ref> While [[K. Eric Drexler|Eric Drexler]] put forth the idea of nano-assemblers working dry, wet nanotech appears to be the likely first area in which something like a nano-assembler may achieve economic results.<ref name="questia"/> [[Pharmaceutical drug|Pharmaceuticals]] and [[Biology|bioscience]] are central features of most nanotech start-ups.<ref name="questia">https://www.questia.com/read/113729011?title=7%3A+Wet+Nanotech ; Book by William Illsey Atkinson "Nanocosm: Nanotechnology and the Big Changes Coming from the Inconceivably Small" (c) 2003</ref> Richard A.L. Jones calls nanotechnology that steals bits of natural nanotechnology and puts them in a synthetic structure ''biokleptic nanotechnology''.<ref name="nottingham"/> He calls building with synthetic materials according to nature's design principles ''biomimetic nanotechnology''.<ref name="nottingham"/>
Using these guiding principles could lead to trillions of nanotech robots, that resemble [[bacteria]] in structural properties, entering a person's [[blood stream]] to do medical treatments.<ref name="nottingham">{{cite web|url=http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/physics/research/nano/pdfs/N15ND05.pdf |accessdate=January 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100120103318/http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/physics/research/nano/pdfs/N15ND05.pdf |archivedate=January 20, 2010 }} Nanotechnology: radical new science or plus ça change?—the debate1</ref>
==Background==
Wet nanotechnology is an anticipated new sub-discipline of nanotech that is going to mostly be dominated by the different forms of [[wet engineering]]. The processes that will be used are going to take place in [[aqueous solutions]] and are very close to that of [[biotechnology]] manufacturing / [[bio-molecular manufacturing]] which is largely concerned with the production of [[biomolecules]] like [[proteins]] and [[DNA]]/[[RNA]].<ref name=Madou>{{cite journal|last=Madou|first=Marc|title=Nanotechnology:dry versus wet engineering?|journal=Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry|date=13 December 2005|volume=384|series=4|issue=6|pages=1–4|doi=10.1007/s00216-005-0182-7}}</ref> There is some overlap of [[Biotech]]nology and Wet nanotechnology because living things are inherently bottom-up engineered and any exploitation of this by biotechnologists means they dabble in bottom-up engineering (though mostly at the level of producing macromolecules like proteins and nucleic acids from there monomer units. Wet nanotech, however, seeks to analyse living things and their components as engineering systems and aims to understand them completely to have complete control of the behavior of the system and to derive principles and methods that can be applied more broadly to bottom up manufacturing, to manipulate matter on the atomic and molecular scales and to creating machines or devices at the nanometer and microscopic scales. Biotech is mostly about exploiting living systems in anyway possible. [[Molecular Biology]] and related disciplines compare the mechanism of function of proteins in particular - and nucleic acids to a lesser extent - as like "molecular machines". In order for engineers to mimic these nanoscale machines in a way that they could be produced with some efficiency, they must look into [[bottom-up manufacturing]]. Bottom-up manufacturing deals with manipulating individual [[atoms]] during the manufacturing process, so that there is absolute control of their placement and interactions.<ref name=Scott>{{cite journal|last=Scott|first=Faye|author2=David Forrest |author3=John Storrs-Hall |author4=Jack Stilgoe |title=Nanotechnology:radical new science or plus ca change?--the debate|journal=Nanotechnology Perceptions|year=2005|pages=119–131|accessdate=}}</ref>
Then from the atomic scale, nanomachines could be made and even be designed to self-replicate themselves as long as they are designed in an environment with copious amount of the needed materials. Because individual atoms are being manipulated in the process, bottom-up manufacturing is often referred to as “atom by atom” manufacturing.<ref name=Scott /> If the manufacturing of nanomachines can be made more readily available through improved techniques, there could be a large economic and social impact. This would start with improvements in making [[MEMS|microelectromechanical systems]] and then would allow for the creation of nanoscale biological sensors along with things that have not been thought of yet.<ref name=Madou /> This is because “wet” nanotech is only in the beginning of its life. Scientists and engineers alike feel that biomimetics is a great way to start looking at creating nanoscale machines.<ref name=Scott /> Humans have only had a few thousand years to try to learn about the mechanics of things at really small scales. However, nature has been working on perfecting the design and functionality of nanomachines for millions of years. This is why there are already nanomachines, such as [[ATP synthase]], working in our bodies that have an unheard of 95% efficiency.<ref name=Bergman>{{cite journal|last=Bergman|first=Jerry|title=ATP: The Perfect Energy Currency for the Cell|journal=Creation Research Society Quarterly|year=1999|volume=36|series=1|pages=1–10}}</ref>
==“Wet” vs. “Dry”==
Wet nanotechnology is a form of wet engineering as opposed to dry engineering.<ref name=Madou /> There are different fields that deal with those two types of engineering. Biologists, from the point of view of nanotechnology, deal with wet engineering. They study processes that happen in [[life]], and for the most part those processes take place in aqueous environments. Our bodies are made up mostly of water.
[[Electrical engineering|Electrical]] and [[mechanical engineers]] are on the other side of the line in dry engineering.<ref name=Madou /> They are involved with processes and manufacturing that does not occur in aqueous environments.
For the most part, wet engineering deals with “soft” materials that allow for [[flexibility]] which is vital at the nanoscale in biological manufacturing. Dry engineers mostly handle things with [[Rigid body|rigid]] structures and parts.<ref name=Scott /> These differences stem for the fact that the forces that the two types of engineers must deal with are very different. At a larger scale, most things are dominated by [[Newtonian physics]]. However, when one looks at the nanoscale, especially in biological matters, the dominating force is [[Brownian motion]].<ref name=Scott />
Because nanotechnology in the new age is going to most likely deal with both dry and wet in conjunction with each other, there is going to have to be a change in the way society looks at engineering and manufacturing. People will have to be not only well educated in engineering but also in biology because the integration of the two is how there will be the largest improvements in nanotechnology.<ref name=Madou />
==Brownian Motion as it relates to Wet Nanotech==
With the existence of natural nanomachines, “a complex precision microscopic-sized machine that fits the standard definition of a machine”,<ref name=Bergman /> such as ATP synthase and [[Enterobacteria phage T4|T4 bacteriophage]], scientists and biologists know that they are capable of making similar types of machines at the same scale.<ref name=Scott /> However, nature has had a long time to perfect the building and creation of these nanomachines and humankind has only just begun to look into them with greater interest.
This interest may have been sparked because of the existence of nanomachines such as ATP synthase ([[adenosine triphosphate]]), which is the “second in importance only to DNA”.<ref name=Bergman /> ATP is the main energy converter that our bodies contain and without it, life as we know it would not be able to flourish or even survive.<ref name=Bergman />
==What does Brownian motion have to do with complex nanomachines?==
Brownian motion is a random, constantly fluctuating force that acts on a body in environments that are at a microscale.<ref name=Scott /> This force is one that mechanical engineers and physicists are not used to dealing with because, at the larger scale that humankind tends to think of things, this force is not one that needs to be taken into account. People think of gravity, inertia, and other physics based forces that act on us all the time, however at the nanoscale those forces are mostly “negligible”.<ref name=Scott />
In order for nanomachines to be recreated by man, either there will need to be discoveries that allow us to understand how to “exploit” Brownian motion as nature does or find a way to work around it by using materials that are rigid enough to stand up to these forces. The way that nature has been able to exploit Brownian motion is through [[self-assembly]]. This force pushes and pulls all of the [[proteins]] and [[amino acids]] around in our bodies and sticks them together in all sorts of combinations. The combinations that do not work separate and continue with their random attachment however, the combinations that do work produce things like ATP synthase.<ref name=Scott /> Through this process nature has been able to make a nanomachine that is 95% efficient, which is a feat that man has not been able to accomplish yet. This is all because nature does not try to work around the forces; it uses them at its advantage.
Growing cells in culture to take advantage of their internal chemical synthesis machinery can be considered a form of nanotechnology but this machinery has also been manipulated outside of living cells.<ref>[http://www.ambion.com/techlib/basics/translation/index.html In Vitro Translation: The Basics]</ref>
